[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (4) |relations=[[Kay Petre]] (wife) |laterwork=[[Solicitor]] }} '''Henry Aloysius Petre''', [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]], [[Military Cross|MC]] (12 June 1884 – 24 April 1962) was an English [[solicitor]] who became Australia's first military aviator and a founding member of the [[Australian Flying Corps]], predecessor of the [[Royal Australian Air Force]]. Born in [[Essex]], he forsook his early legal career to pursue an interest in aviation, building his own aeroplane and gaining employment as a designer and pilot. In 1912, he answered the Australian [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Defence Department]]'s call for pilots to form an aviation school, and was commissioned a [[lieutenant]] in the [[Australian Military Forces]]. The following year, he chose the site of the country's first air base at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|Point Cook]], Victoria, and established its inaugural training institution, the [[Central Flying School RAAF|Central Flying School]], with [[Eric Harrison (RAAF officer)|Eric Harrison]]. Shortly after the outbreak of World War I, Petre was appointed commander of the [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]], the first unit of the newly formed Australian Flying Corps to see active service. He led the Half Flight through the [[Battle of Es Sinn|Battles of Es Sinn]] and [[Battle of Ctesiphon (1915)|Ctesiphon]], and the [[Siege of Kut]]. His actions in the Middle East earned him the [[Distinguished Service Order]], the [[Military Cross]], and four [[Mentioned in Despatches|mentions in despatches]]. Transferring to the [[Royal Air Force]] as a [[major]] in 1918, he commanded [[No. 75 Squadron RAF|No. 75 Squadron]] before retiring from the military the following year. Petre resumed his legal practice in England, and continued to fly recreationally before his death in 1962, aged seventy-seven. He was married to racing driver [[Kay Petre]]. ==Early career== Born on 12 June 1884 at [[Ingatestone]], [[Essex]], Petre (pronounced "Peter")Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', xv was the son of Sebastian Henry Petre and his wife Catharine. He was schooled at [[Mount St Mary's College]], [[Chesterfield]], before following his father into law and becoming a [[solicitor]] in 1905.Garrisson, "Petre, Henry Aloysius (1884–1962)" Inspired by [[Louis Blériot]]'s pioneering [[English Channel|cross-channel]] flight in July 1909, Petre gave up his legal practice, borrowed £250 and proceeded to build his own aeroplane, with design assistance from his brother Edward, an architect.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 2–4{{cite magazine | title = The Yorkshire Disaster | magazine = [[Flight International|Flight]] | volume=V |issue=1 |pages=10 | date = 4 January 1913 | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200010.html | accessdate =4 February 2011}}{{cite web|title=Retail price index comparison|url=https://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php?year_source=1909&amount=250&year_result=2015 |publisher=Measuring Worth|accessdate=6 June 2016}} Having spent six months on its construction, Petre crashed the machine on its maiden flight.Stephens; Isaacs, ''High Fliers'', pp. 9–11Odgers, ''Air Force Australia'', pp. 13–14 Uninjured and undiscouraged, he borrowed a further £25, took flying lessons at [[Brooklands|Brooklands Airfield]] in [[Surrey]], and obtained [[Royal Aero Club]] [[List of pilots awarded an Aviator's Certificate by the Royal Aero Club in 1911|Aviator's Certificate No. 128]] on 12 September 1911. He became an instructor at Brooklands' [[Deperdussin|Deperdussin School]], and later its chief, prior to taking up employment as a designer and pilot with [[Handley Page|Handley Page Limited]] in 1912. Characterised by [[Australia in the War of 1939–1945|official RAAF historian]] Douglas Gillison as "quiet and academic by nature", and coming from a long line of [[Holy Orders (Catholic Church)|Catholic clergy]], Petre was nicknamed "Peter the Monk".Campbell-Wright, ''An Interesting Point'', pp. 12, 18–19 On Christmas Eve 1912, Edward Petre, who was known as "Peter the Painter", was killed in an accident at [[Marske-by-the-Sea]], Yorkshire, while attempting to fly from Brooklands to [[Edinburgh]]. [[File:A03915PetreHarrison1914.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Lieutenants Petre (left) and Harrison (right) in a B.E.2 at Central Flying School, Point Cook, 1914|alt=Two men in flying gear seated in tandem open cockpits of a biplane with a four-bladed propeller]] In December 1911, the Australian Defence Department had advertised in the United Kingdom for "two competent mechanists and aviators" to establish a flying corps and school.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/33.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force 1939–1942'', pp. 710–711] From among fifty applications, Petre was chosen and commissioned as a [[lieutenant]] in the [[Australian Military Forces]], his appointment on 6 August 1912 making him the nation's first military pilot. The other appointee, [[Eric Harrison (RAAF officer)|Eric Harrison]], joined him later that year. Petre arrived in Australia in January 1913, his first task being to choose a site for the proposed [[Central Flying School RAAF|Central Flying School]] (CFS), which he was to command. After travelling hundreds of kilometres on his motorcycle, and rejecting the government's preferred location near the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], in [[Canberra]], he selected {{convert|297|hectare|acre}} at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|Point Cook]], Victoria, to become, as [[George Odgers]] described it, the "birthplace of Australian military aviation". Unlike the alternative site near Duntroon, Point Cook was flat, close to the coast and not, in Petre's own words, "isolated in the bush".Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 6 He and Harrison established CFS over the following year with four mechanics, three other staff, and five aircraft including two Deperdussin monoplanes, two [[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2]] biplanes, and a [[Bristol Boxkite]] for initial training. Harrison made the unit's first flight in the Boxkite on Sunday, 1 March 1914, while Petre, taking off in a Deperdussin later that day, registered its first accident when he crashed after snaring his tailplane in telephone wires.{{cite magazine | last = Wellfare | first = John | title = Alone in the dark | magazine =Air Force News | volume=47 |issue=6 |pages=426–427 | date = 21 April 2005 | url =http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4706/features/feature01.htm | accessdate =4 February 2011}} Its coterie of personnel by now being referred to as the [[Australian Flying Corps]], CFS commenced its first flying course on 17 August, two weeks after the outbreak of World War I. The four students included Captain [[Thomas White (Australian politician)|Thomas White]] and Lieutenants [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]], George Merz, and David Manwell; Harrison was responsible for initial training and Petre for advanced instruction. ==World War I== [[File:A04131CaudronMesopotamia1916.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Caudron G.3 of the Mesopotamian Half Flight|alt=Front view of single-engined biplane and two men in front of a large open hangar]] On 8 February 1915, the Australian government received a request from the [[British Raj|British Government of India]] for aerial assistance in the [[Mesopotamian campaign|campaign against the Turks in Mesopotamia]]. Aircrew and supporting personnel for half a [[Flight (military unit)|flight]] only were available so the unit, the AFC's first to see active service, became known as the [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]]. Promoted to [[Captain (OF-2)|captain]], Petre was appointed the Half Flight's commanding officer and embarked for [[Basra]] via [[Bombay]] on 14 April, later to be joined by fellow pilots White, Merz and Lieutenant William Treloar, along with thirty-seven ground staff.Cutlack, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/9/chapters/01.pdf ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp. 1–3]Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', pp. 4–9 In Mesopotamia, Petre was required to lead the AFC contingent in [[aerial reconnaissance|reconnaissance]] and [[sabotage]] missions, and had to deal with unreliable machines, hazardous terrain, and the threat of incarceration or death at the hands of hostile tribesmen. He took part in operations in the [[Amarah|Amara]] area from 31 May to 4 June, for which he was [[mentioned in despatches]].{{LondonGazette|issue=29536 |supp=yes|startpage=3661|date=5 April 1916|accessdate=26 October 2009}} The obsolete aircraft supplied by the Indian Government, two [[Maurice Farman Shorthorn]]s and a [[Maurice Farman Longhorn]], were only capable of top speeds of 50 mph (80 km/h), while the desert wind (known as the ''[[shamal (wind)|shamal]]'') could reach 80 mph (129 km/h), meaning that the aircraft often made no headway or were simply blown backwards. In July, the Half Flight's equipment was augmented by two [[Caudron G.3]] aircraft, a marginal improvement on the Farmans, but still prone to mechanical failure. Later that month, one of the Caudrons was forced to land in enemy territory. Its crew, Merz and a New Zealander, were never seen again; they were later reported killed by Arabs after a running gun battle over several miles.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 5–8 [[File:A02253Petre1915.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Captain Petre (far left), Captain White (second left) and Lieutenant Merz (far right) of the Mesopotamian Half Flight at Basra, July 1915|alt=Four men in khaki military uniforms, two wearing pith helmets (one of whom has his arm in a sling), seated in front of a boy]] On 24 August, the Half Flight was augmented by four [[Martinsyde]] S1s and redesignated [[No. 30 Squadron RAF|No. 30 Squadron]], [[Royal Flying Corps]] (RFC). The squadron moved into [[Kut]] following the city's capture by the Allies during the [[Battle of Es Sinn]] in September;Cutlack, ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp. 11–13 for his part in the operation, Petre was again mentioned in despatches.{{LondonGazette|issue=29536 |supp=yes|startpage=3665|endpage=3666|date=5 April 1916|accessdate=26 October 2009}} Over the following two months, however, both Treloar and White were captured and became [[Prisoner of war|prisoners of war]], leaving Petre as the only pilot remaining from the original Half Flight. Around the time of the [[Battle of Ctesiphon (1915)|Battle of Ctesiphon]] in November, he devised an implement shaped like a small [[Rake (tool)|garden rake]] that allowed him to accurately measure ground distances from the air in order to better map the desert terrain.Cutlack, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/9/chapters/02.pdf ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp. 21–22] During the [[Siege of Kut]] between December 1915 and April 1916, he flew a series of missions using crude parachutes to airdrop grain supplies (and a [[millstone]] for grinding), medical supplies and equipment to the town's entrapped garrison, which included nine of his AFC mechanics.Odgers, ''Air Force Australia'', p. 23 Petre was awarded the [[Military Cross]] on 14 January 1916,{{LondonGazette|issue=29438 |supp=yes|startpage=590|date=14 January 1916|accessdate=26 October 2009}} and was mentioned in despatches twice more over the course of the year.{{LondonGazette|issue=29665|supp=yes|startpage=6959|endpage=6960|date=13 July 1916|accessdate=26 October 2009}}{{LondonGazette|issue=29789|supp=yes|startpage=10047|endpage=10049|date=19 October 1916|accessdate=26 October 2009}} In May 1916 he contracted [[typhoid]] and was sent to India for recuperation.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 23 He transferred out of No. 30 Squadron in December,Dennis et al., ''The Oxford Companion to Australian Military History'', p. 420 and was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] the same month.{{LondonGazette|issue=29876 |supp=yes|startpage=12555|date=22 December 1916|accessdate=26 October 2009}} In February 1917, he was posted to France with [[No. 15 Squadron RAF|No. 15 Squadron RFC]], a reconnaissance unit operating B.E.2s.{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/organisation/15squadron.cfm|title=15 (R) Squadron|publisher =[[Royal Air Force]]|accessdate=6 June 2016}} Two months later his youngest brother John, a squadron commander in the [[Royal Naval Air Service]] and a [[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Service Cross]] recipient, was killed in a flying accident.{{cite magazine | title = Personals | magazine = Flight | volume=IX |issue=18 |pages=421 | date = 3 May 1917 | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1917/1917%20-%200421.html | accessdate =30 April 2012}} Petre subsequently returned to England and took charge of [[No. 5 Squadron RAAF|No. 5 Squadron AFC]] (also known as No. 29 Squadron RFC), a training unit for Australian [[Fighter aircraft|fighter]] pilots, particularly those destined for Palestine.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_10845.asp |title=5 (Training) Squadron AFC|publisher= [[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=6 June 2016}}Odgers, ''Air Force Australia'', p. 37 He had hoped to command [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron AFC]] in Palestine but received an adverse report concerning his leadership abilities, and the position went to Richard Williams.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp. 342–343 Petre was discharged from the AFC as a [[major]] on 31 January 1918, to take a commission with the RFC.{{cite web|url=https://aif.adfa.edu.au/showPerson?pid=239676|title= Henry Aloysius Petre|work= The AIF Project|accessdate=6 June 2016}} In April that year, he transferred to the newly formed [[Royal Air Force]], establishing and commanding [[No. 75 Squadron RAF|No. 75 (Home Defence) Squadron]]. ==Later life and legacy== [[File:A04588WilliamsPetreHarrison1914.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Instructors and students of the first CFS course at Point Cook in 1914: [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]] and [[Thomas White (Australian politician)|Thomas White]] (back row); George Merz, Henry Petre, [[Eric Harrison (RAAF officer)|Eric Harrison]], and David Manwell (front row)|alt=Six men in military uniforms with peaked caps, two standing and four seated, in front of a biplane]] Petre retired from the RAF on 15 September 1919, and resumed practice as a solicitor in London. He married Kathleen Defries, a Canadian, in 1929. Petre introduced Kathleen to racing cars and, as [[Kay Petre]], she became one of Britain's leading female drivers of the 1930s.Bouzanque, ''Fast Ladies'', pp. 80–82 Henry Petre maintained his interest in aviation for the rest of his life, taking up competitive gliding and, more than thirty years after his first flight in 1911, still delighted in "taking an [[Auster]] for a spin".{{cite magazine | title = The International Gliding Commission | magazine = Flight | volume=XXIII |issue=41 |pages=1019–1021 | date = 9 October 1931 | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1931/1931%20-%201091.html | accessdate =30 April 2012}} In 1951, he received the Royal Aero Club's Silver Medal for his long record of active flying.{{cite magazine | last=White | first=Thomas | authorlink = Thomas White (Australian politician) | title = The RAAF is thirty | magazine =Flight | pages = 426–427 | date = 13 April 1951 | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1951/1951%20-%200688.html | accessdate =4 February 2011}} He visited Australia for the first time in forty-five years in 1961, and was photographed sitting in the cockpit of the same Deperdussin—by then an exhibit at [[RAAF Museum]]—that he had flown at Point Cook in 1914.{{cite magazine | title = Fifty years of military aviation in Australia | magazine = Flight International | volume=85 |issue=2870 |pages= 396 | date = 12 March 1964 | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1964/1964%20-%200673.html | accessdate =30 April 2012}}{{cite magazine | title = Mechanist aviators | magazine = Flight International | volume=79 |issue=2712 |pages=287 | date = 3 March 1961 | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1961/1961%20-%200283.html | accessdate =30 April 2012}} Having retired from his legal practice in 1958, Henry Petre died in London on 24 April 1962, and was survived by Kay, who died in 1991. In a retrospective on the RAAF in November 1939, [[Flight International|''Flight'']] magazine described Henry Petre and Eric Harrison as "the fathers of military aviation in Australia".{{cite magazine | last = Terry | first = Michael | title = Evolution of RAAF | magazine = Flight | volume=XXXVI |issue=1612 |pages=387 | date = 16 November 1939 | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1939/1939-1-%20-%201241.html | accessdate =30 April 2012}} Though Harrison, through his longer association with Australian service flying as a founding member of the Royal Australian Air Force in 1921 and his career up until the end of World War II, was generally regarded as the "Father of the RAAF" until [[Air Marshal]] Richard Williams assumed that mantle, Douglas Gillison considered Petre "equally entitled" to such an accolade. In his volume on the Air Force for The Australian Centenary History of Defence in 2001, Alan Stephens noted that Petre made "the greater contribution to the establishment of Point Cook and the Central Flying School", concluding that "perhaps any judgement would not only be moot but also gratuitous, as by circumstance and achievement both men properly belong in the pantheon of the RAAF". ==Notes==
